description.narrative:
Expected Results The peace process in Yemen is supported with fast, flexible initiatives, that deliver tangible, rapid improvements in the daily lives of people, and reinforce and build public support for the political process.
Under this output the following components will be implemented:
Component 1: Initiatives to build confidence between the parties, in the peace process and to support the implementation of the Stockholm agreement or any other future agreements.
Component 2: Discreet activities emerging out of existing Track II initiatives are implemented with the goal of catalyzing the political process.
Component 3: Transitional governance arrangements are supported as and when the parties agree.

Stöd till en fredsfond som ska stärka förutsättningarna att genomföra överenskomna steg (genom Stockholmsavtalet, december 2018) mot en fredlig lösning av konflikten i Jemen. Fredsfonden är utformad för att stödja fredsprocessen med snabba, flexibla initativ som överenskommits av partnerna och som levererar konkreta, snabba förbättringar i människors dagliga liv och förstärker och bygger offentligt stöd för den politiska processen.

Support to a Peace Support Facility which aims at strenthening the possibilites of the implementation of the Stockholm agreement to enhace the prerequisites for a peaceful solution of the conflict in Yemen. The Facility is designed to support the peace process with fast, flexible initiatives, agreed by the parties, that deliver tangible, rapid improvements in the daily lives of people and reinforce and build public support for the political process.

tag.narrative: 16.1 - Avsevärt minska alla former av våld och dödligt våld överallt.
16.1 - Significantly reduce all forms of violence and related death rates everywhere.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

title.narrative: Third party cost sharing agreement UNDP-Sida för Yemen Peace Support Facility
Beslut om insats Jemen Pece Support Facility 2019-2022

description.narrative:
In 2021, the work of the PSF was largely undertaken in two separate lines of effort. The first focused on the support to the peace efforts, particularly centered around support to the rehabilitation of the port of Hodeidah through the first window as well as support to Track 2 efforts through the second window of the Facility. The second line of effort revolved around support to the inspection and light maintenance of the FSO Safer. In the second quarter of 2021, the PSF also undertook a Mid-Term Evaluation.
The Facility's work to support the dialogue efforts have been slow also in 2021. Dialogue between the parties has not materialized in 2021, and the prospects for talks have been reduced by continued escalation and attempts by the Houthis to seize Marib. In the wake of this, the Facility has continued to implement the rehabilitation work in Hodeidah Port, including procurement of tugboat, spare parts, 27 buoys, work to rehabilitate generator capacities, slipways and berths in the port. The PSF has also continued to expand its work with Track 2 partners, and in 2021 three separate Track 2 initiatives received funding from the PSF (Safer Schools, CIVIC Dialogues, and PIPLG Dialogues). This work has progressed, albeit seemingly slow given delays in permissions and acceptance, and the more strategic question also remains whether the work at Track 2 level can/should be expected to have an impact on the Track 1 efforts.
The Facility's work to support the inspection and light maintenance of the FSO Safer has been equally challenging. There was seeming momentum at the beginning of 2021, however continued delays and obstructions from the Houthis (including coming with additional requests to the Scope of Work, delaying issuance of visas for experts etc.) have resulted in the mission not being able to materialize. In the second quarter, Ambassadors of Member States who are funding and supporting the mission sent a letter to Ansar Allah leadership in an attempt to put pressure on the movement to work with the UN and facilitate the efforts to allow the inspection and maintenance to take place, but to no avail. Shortly thereafter, the relationship between Ansar Allah and the UN (in particular UNOPS who was leading on the implementation of the initiative) deteriorated and over the summer the dialogue completely stalled. In September, the United Nations decided to move the FSO Safer file from the Office of the Special Envoy to Yemen (OSESGY) to the Office of the Resident Coordinator for Yemen (RCO). In the fourth quarter of 2021, a recruitment of a senior level focal point to be based in the RCO and coordinate the UN system response on the FSO Safer was underway. A programmatic review was also in progress to understand how the work can be taken forward, with an ambition to move the work from UNOPS to UNDP. The new proposal would see UNDP work closely with SMIT Salvage (a Dutch shipping company) and Fahem Group (a Yemeni company that works with food imports in Yemen) to support the procurement of a Very Large Crude Carrying (VLCC) vessel that would replace the FSO Safer, where the latter would be scrapped. The solution is expected to cost 56MUSD, 35MUSD of which is expected to be generated by the sale of the FSO Safer and the remainder which would need to be mobilized. While the entire operation is expected to take around 120 days, security and permit restrictions, the funding gap and resistance on the Houthi side to allow for inspection of the FSO Safer all constitute hurdles that the new approach will need to contend with.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
